title: chancellor philip hammond claims britain
story: NewsChancellor Philip Hammond claims Britain will BOOM with a Brexit 'deal idend' in wildly optimistic Tory conference speechIn a huge hostage to fortune, the Chancellor claimed the economy will soar as soon as the Prime Minister brings back an as-yet-unknown package from BrusselsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor12:58, 1 OCT 2018Updated13:21, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/philip-hammond-claims-therell-brexit-13340684,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPhilip Hammond today claimed services like the NHS will get a 'Brexit deal idend' within WEEKS in a wildly bullish speech to the Tory party conference. In a huge hostage to fortune, the Chancellor claimed the economy will boom as soon as the Prime Minister brings back an as-yet-unknown package from Brussels - which MPs could still vote down. The new plea was aimed squarely at Tory Brexiteers who are threatening to vote down the deal Mrs May hopes to bring back in just a few weeks' time. It is the pro-Remain Chancellor's version of the much-disputed claim that Brexit itself will bring a 'idend' for the NHS - after 2020, when payments to Brussels are cut. Mr Hammond has been known as one of the most gloomy ministers on Brexit. Only this morning he admitted firms were sitting on their hands due to deadlock in talks with Brussels. Yet addressing Conservative members in Birmingham today, he claimed: I'm going to stick my neck out here today and make a prediction to you - that when the Prime Minister gets a deal agreed there will be a boost to our economic growth.  A 'deal idend', which we will share in line with our balanced approach between keeping taxes low, supporting public services, reducing the deficit, and investing in Britain's future. But Mr Hammond also said preparations for no deal are continuing. I will maintain enough fiscal firepower in my locker to support our economy  that happens, he said. In a wide-ranging speech that quoted Margaret Thatcher and free market economist Adam Smith, Mr Hammond vowed not to outbid Jeremy Corbyn's Labour party and said Tories must reclaim 21st century capitalism. Ripping off Labour's 'for the many not the few' slogan, he declared Tories must reassure the very many who will worry about what new technologies mean for their job security - worry that the gains will be made by the few.  And he said Conservatives are faced with an “urgent mission” to persuade voters to avoid “dangerous and seductive populism led by Jeremy Corbyn - who is totally unfit to govern this country. The Chancellor declared: We will not outbid Corbyn with short-term gimmicks that cause long-term damage. We will not outspend him with reckless borrowing. We will not promise the illusory utopia he offers. Because, as those who have tried it have shown time and time again, it is based on a lie and it always ends in tears. He added: Corbyn boasts that Labour are a government in waiting. Well, I say let’s keep him waiting - this year, next year and every year. Elsewhere Mr Hammond announced a &pound125 million package to change the distribution of the Tories' 'apprenticeship levy' after concerns over how well the system was working. Measures include allowing large employers to transfer up to 25% of their apprenticeship levy funds to businesses in their supply chain from April next year.  He also announced &pound100million for a 'National Retraining Scheme' in partnership with the CBI and the TUC.  The Chancellor also warned robots will be the biggest threat on the horizon - and a huge opportunity. In the next decade or so, Articial Intelligence, self-driving cars, personalized medicine, virtual reality, advanced robotics and many, many other cutting-edge developments will all begin to transform our lives, he said. A future where cars don’t pollute, and we’ve all but eliminated traffic accidents Where you are able to order and 3D print a product at home, instead of waiting for it to be delivered Where cancer is tamed, so that fewer of us have to go through the heartache of losing a loved one to this cruel disease. All of this is science fact not fiction. Despite his reputation - and telling a string of jokes that no one laughed at - the Chancellor insisted: I am an optimist. I've heard some call me glass half full Phil. It depends who's buying.

title: defiant message tory conference stop
story: NewsopinionMy defiant message to Tory conference: stop the austerity and give people some bloody helpThe Mirror's Ros Wynne-Jones told the Conservatives what le is really like in 21st century Britain. You can read her speech hereShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist19:00, 30 SEP 2018Updated20:26, 30 SEP 2018NewsopinionRos Wynne-Jones confronted the Tories on the rise in rough sleepers "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThank you very much for having me here today to the Conservative Conference fringe. I have to confess it’s not a place I’ve been to before. But  we’re to change the lives of any of the people I write about, you are the people I need to convince that things desperately need changing in our country. And I’d like to thank you for trying to listen to voices outside of your own political mainstream. All of our politics on every side suffer from the silos we are trapped in and can’t climb out of. So, thank you. It’s always a pleasure to be in Birmingham, and particularly relevant to what I’m going to say today as it’s the city we started our Wigan Pier Project from. For the past two years we’ve been retracing George Orwell’s Road to Wigan Pier and he set out from here in the Midlands.  When we began our journey in January 2017, I’d read about the growing cardboard city in Birmingham, and I came to interview homeless people at a breakfast service. It was a bitterly cold morning when I got off the train from London, so cold that my feet froze on the walk from the station, and when I got to the breakfast place there was a queue twice round the block. All the homeless people were talking about a young man who had died overnight in sub-zero temperatures. When I found the place he’d died, a little carpark on John Bright Street, less than 15 minutes’ walk from here, someone had already taken the warm and dry patch he’d died on – dragging their filthy duvet over a broken-down cardboard box. The people we went on to interview over the next few days and weeks, could literally break your heart. A veteran in a wheelchair who had been RPGd. A man who told us about all the homeless people he knew who had thrown themselves off buildings. An amazing homeless band called the Dissenters. Who knew that ‘Broken Britain’ wasn’t a slogan but an ambition? No-one in this room can deny that homelessness in this country has grown exponentially in this country since 2010 when the Conservative Party came to power and David Cameron announced the ‘Age of Austerity’. Just walk round here tonight for a few minutes and you’ll see homeless people all over the city, just as you’ll see them in London and Manchester and Liverpool and Blackpool and Hastings and yes, even in Windsor, where a Tory council wanted them removed for spoiling the Royal Wedding. So, no it’s not just Birmingham, but there’s still something amazing about how the Conservative Party always comes and holds its party conference here. Something geographically appealing about its centrality I imagine. And yet. Look at the Midlands: Birmingham City Council’s budget has been slashed by an eyewatering 40 per cent. By 2025 the Council budget will have lost three-quarters of a billion pounds. Look at the crisis at Birmingham Prison this summer. The collapse at Northamptonshire County Council. Recent figures showing that childcare costs have risen nine times faster than wages in the West Midlands since 2008. The fact that yesterday a group of Birmingham home care workers, mostly low paid women, lead a march through the city. I know it’s must be easy to dismiss these people as Marxist agitators – but what  they are just homecare workers whose services have been devastated by privatisation? Who work under minimum wage because they won’t leave old people in wet pads, but who work for skeleton companies owned by hedge funds? When George Orwell set off from Birmingham in 1936, it was because he understood there were two Britains. A well-off Britain that was more than comfortable. And a Britain barely surviving in the industrial north and Midlands. What he came to see, as he travelled through the north, I believe, was something even more serious – that the sweat of one Britain was enabling the comfort of the other Britain. That’s never been more true in our Britain today – where one person’s ability to order a perfectly chilled bottle of wine instantly and cheaply from Amazon Prime, relies on the sweat of another person toiling in a windowless workhouse. Are these people left behind? Those people working in reinvented Victorian insecurity? Those people for whom the inflated housing market inflated that bit too far? For whom the welfare safety net has been slashed beyond recognition? The people working three jobs who are still sometimes skipping meals so their children can eat? Like Orwell, I think we need to question language at every turn. Austerity did this, of course it did – but it was enabled by language, by words serving a political narrative. It’s language – the language of strivers and scroungers, the language of racist ide and rule, separating the working classes so they are isible by the colour of their skin, that has led to this mess in the first place. The repulsive language of Leave and the patronising, hectoring language of Remain. So, I have to start by asking what you mean by ‘Left Behind Britain’? Do you mean some people weren’t All In It Together after all? Left behind sounds like someone that missed the bus. Maybe they were a bit too slow to get on board. Maybe they weren’t modern people, stuck in their ways. The angry, jittery, poverty-stricken, Brexit-y parts of Britain aren’t ‘left behind’. They have been Held Back from getting on the bus in the first place. As a direct result of policies that have been developed at Tory conferences like this one. By the attack on their support through welfare reform. By the cuts to their schools and the services for kids that need extra help. By the closure of the Sure Start centres that used to help level the early years playing fields. By the closure of the libraries where they used to search for jobs, and borrow books and do their homework. By the lack of hope inherent in walking down boarded up high streets every day. You can call them Just About Managing. I call them in crisis, in debt, and incandescent. Anyway – two years ago, an unnecessary vote called by a Conservative Prime Minister who was trying to outwit a flank of his party, offered Held Back people a lightning rod moment.  It still might not have been defining, but the Tory-led Remain campaign pushed them further and further to the wall. Threatening them. Bullying them. Filling the airwaves with the spiralising classes – the patronising Smoothie Millionaires. It was the worst run political campaign in living memory that learned nothing from the insurgent ‘Yes’ campaign that nearly won in Scotland, and everything from the ‘No’ campaign that nearly lost. No wonder millions of people decided it was the moment to speak up. Did we listen? No. Did we hell.  The wall between the silos has actually thickened. Leaving screaming voices desperate to be heard, shut out again, pushed ever further from the centre and into the arms of St Tommy Robinson. In 1936, Orwell watched the same phenomenon, encountering Oswald Mosley on his Road to Wigan Pier. It’s kind of beautul in its circularity. The poorest people vote against the EU that protected their rights and now the richest people will get even richer and capitalism ever more unfettered and rampant. Who wins? Extreme capitalism. The people who funded Vote Leave. Meanwhile in a Britain just outside this shiny city centre, high streets where libraries once stood stand empty, and homeless people huddle in shop doorways and mental health services are closed down and cafes have been replaced by betting shops and cash converters where people queue at 8am on a Monday morning holding their worldly goods in cardboard boxes tied with string. These people haven’t been ‘left behind’. It’s far more sinister than that. The people who did the least to cause the banking crisis have been made to pay for it. We weren’t all in it together, not even close. They’ve not been Left Behind – they’ve been evaded, by those companies who not only evade their taxes but evade their workers’ rights too by the use of shady agency companies straight out of Charles Dickens. They have been Held Back by welfare ‘reform’ – a term I use in its loosest sense. Because nothing better has come from the Bedroom Tax or the shambles of Personal Independence Payments – or from the bitter pill of Universal Credit. There’s no point saying that the principle of UC isn’t a bad one, when it contains at its very core a deep cut – a five to eight week wait with no money coming in.  I can’t go into everything that’s wrong with the government’s welfare reform programme in 5 minutes. But in its simplest terms –  you go to the foodbank – there’s one less than half a mile from here – and ask what people are doing in there you will 99 per cent likely be told one of three things. Benefit delays, sanctions, or insecure work. None of them an accident. They were part of a devised political plan. To make Austerity work there had to be human collateral, and that has been the poorest and most powerless and vulnerable people in society. There’s even been a particularly nasty narrative alongside it, the scroungers narrative. Who would care about what’s happening to them? The hostile environment created by policies that came out of this conference, was not just for immigrants. It’s your party that has been hijacked by extremists.  If you go to the Easterhouse estate, where Iain Duncan Smith wept, and had his Damascene moment and ask the people there, as I have, whether any of them – ANY – are better off you will be extremely lucky to find a single soul. Even the bloke who showed him round was ashamed. That is the level of total failure and misery I am asking you to confront today. Meanwhile, insecure work is not a fact of le but a symptom of how the 1950s sunny uplands maidens-on-bicycles capitalism beloved of this conference has failed all but wealthiest in this country. Enabled by another myth – that of ‘trickle down wealth’. Funnily enough it was a trickle, a trickle too small to see. But it cascaded at the top, where the rich have got richer and richer and richer since the crash. It’s not the 1950s any more.

title: found most embarrassing event tory
story: NewsopinionI found the most embarrassing event at Tory conference and you almost certainly didn't see itJeremy Wright probably would have got a bigger crowd for his speech  he hadn't turned up - and that was originally the planShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter18:12, 1 OCT 2018NewsopinionJeremy Wright addresses the masses "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailImagine you’re a Cabinet Minister. Now imagine being in the situation where more people would have turned up to see your speech  you hadn’t turned up yourself. That’s the position Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright was in this afternoon. You see, Jeremy was originally supposed to deliver his speech to Conservative Party Conference as a hologram. A projection. A digital apparition. It was the brainchild of his predecessor, Matt Hancock - now Health Secretary, and much more comfortable in the ‘Minister of Fun’ brief than Wright. You remember him. He’s the one who did Parkour.  And had his own app - called Matt Hancock - which wasn’t very good, but at the very least didn’t leak the Defence Secretary’s mobile number to literally anyone who wanted it. Before Theresa May’s last reshuffle, The Right Honourable Jeremy Wright QC was the attorney general. The government’s top lawyer.  I’ve seen Wright deliver learned, competent speeches about tricky subjects like cyber security. He was quite good at it.  Which made his move to Culture, where he'd have to talk about sport  and music  even more baffling. But while the hologram stunt might have been infinitely better suited to Matt Hancock's talents, at least it would have given Jeremy a bit of pizazz.   Wright, a curious charisma vacuum, took to the stage to tell an anecdote about his school play to a concert hall barely busier than the upper room was for the Last Supper. “When I was 13, I was shy and didn't much like being the centre of attention. I’ve changed,” he joked, fooling nobody. He went on: “But that year I was persuaded to take a large part in a school play. “The effect on my self-confidence, on what I felt I could do, was signicant and long-lasting. “So much so that I feel able to say to you that  I had not stood on that stage then, I would not be standing on this stage now.”  It’s hard to think that when Wright wrote those lines into his speech, he’d imagined delivering them them to a crowd which could have comfortably fit in the school hall which saw his theatrical debut. A conservative estimate - pun intended - put the size of the party faithful somewhere just south of 200, scattered through the four levels of Birmingham’s cavernous Symphony Hall. I genuinely just went into the hall to see how sparse the crowd was, but so empty was the auditorium I almost felt obliged to keep my seat until the end of his address to make up the numbers. It’s not just him, though he was the most pathetic example. There were plenty of seats free for Chancellor Philip Hammond’s speech. There was no compunction to turn up early for Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, or even Tory conference favourite Ruth Davidson, who gave a speech which hit all the right notes, but was never going to win a Grammy.

title: tory dominic raab admits no
story: NewsTory Dominic Raab admits No Deal Brexit could be used to hand corporations a massive tax cutDominic Raab said the government will “pull every lever we've got” to ease business “disruption”  the UK leaves the EU with no agreement in March 2019Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor19:11, 1 OCT 2018Updated19:15, 1 OCT 2018NewsDominic Raab has an opportunity - but will it be one for big business? "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tory ministers could hand corporate giants a massive tax cut in a No Deal Brexit , a top Cabinet figure revealed tonight.  Dominic Raab said the government will “pull every lever we've got” to ease business “disruption”  the UK leaves the EU with no agreement in March 2019. The Brexit Secretary even left open a radical idea of slashing corporation tax from 19% to 10% - which would firms a huge tax break while millions of working families struggle. He spoke on the fringes of the Tory conference hours after Chancellor Philip Hammond said he was reserving “fiscal firepower” to “support the economy” in No Deal Brexit.  Mr Raab was asked his view on an idea by Chloe Westley, of the right-wing TaxPayers Alliance think tank, of dropping corporation tax to 10% - and using tax to get a “post-Brexit boom”. The Cabinet minister replied: “You just said Chloe wants to reduce corporation tax to 10% - and the Chancellor's talked about reserving fiscal firepower in the case of no deal. “What more do you want? “Of course he's talking about the recognition that actually, in the no deal scenario, we want to pull every lever we've got to see us through what short term buffeting or disruption we have. “I think the Chancellor gave a brilliant speech and it shows you we're all rowing the same boat.”  Mr Raab is a free marketeer who in 2011 proposed scrapping the minimum wage for some under-21s. Indicating other Cabinet ministers may back his view, Mr Raab laughed and added: “People were coming to this conference expecting it to be dynamite. “Actually now the journalists are all complaining to me that there's not really much going on, there seems to be far too much of people singing from the same hymn sheet.” “I think the Chancellor gave a great speech, not just talking about what we would do in no deal, but talking about the advantages economically for the country  we get the Chequers deal across the line.” It comes days after Theresa May pledged to cut Brexit Britain's corporation tax rate to the lowest in the G20 – a title currently held by Singapore on 17%. Tory governments have already slashed the rate from 28% in 2010. With weeks left to secure a deal, Mr Raab suggested EU chiefs had “weaponised” the deadlock over the Irish border to get leverage. “I think there has been a bit of that,” he said. “There is no doubt there are some that have enjoyed politicising this issue – I say enjoyed, have taken the opportunity.”

title: tory immigration minister squirms refuses
story: NewsTory immigration minister squirms as she refuses FOUR times to answer a straight question about WindrushThe Prime Minister apologised to victims but refused to say that the Home Office policies responsible for the scandal were wrongShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent14:57, 1 OCT 2018Updated15:27, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/tory-immigration-minister-dodges-windrush-13341277,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory immigration minister squirmed as she refused to give a straight answer on Windrush. Caroline Nokes was asked whether Theresa May had been right not to apologise for the Hostile Environment policy. Questioned about Windrush by Andrew Marr, the Prime Minister apologised to victims but refused to say that the Home Office policies responsible for the scandal were wrong. As Home Secretary Mrs May famously vowed to create a hostile environment for illegal immigrants. Critics say this led to a surge in members of the Windrush generation - Commonwealth-born migrants who came to Britain before 1973 - being wrongly told to produce documents or leave the country. All those who arrived before 1973 had the right to stay but the Home Office destroyed arrival documents, and many did not have the right paperwork. Today Ms Nokes looked uncomfortable as she was asked whether Mrs May made the right call.  She told Talk Radio's Ross Kempsell: We've been very clear that we have a compliant environment. That makes sure that people who are legally entitled to be in this country can benefit from the services and the advantages of being here. But those who are not here legally, that there are measures in place to make sure they can't benefit from those same services.  Theresa May squirms on live TV as she refuses to apologise for 'hostile environment' that sparked Windrush scandal  I think it's absolutely right that we should have apologised to the Windrush Generation and I have done so and I have been privileged to be able to meet members and apologise to them in person and for me that was a very important thing to do. But it's absolutely right that we continue to have policies that make sure we can run a fair immigration policy. She was pressed a second time on whether Mrs May should have apologised for the policy. Ms Nokes replied: We have a compliant environment policy. The Prime Minister the Home Secretary, indeed the former Home Secretary have all used the term compliant environment. It was a Labour Home Secretary that first introduced the term hostility. But actually what we want is a fair immigration policy that enables those who are here legally to benefit from services from being able to rent property and work.

title: tory philip hammond deliberately used
story: NewsTory Philip Hammond 'deliberately used Brexit forecasts he knew were wrong' in No Deal plansThe former Brexit secretary accused Mr Hammond of undermining negotiations and claimed he turned predictions about the impact of crashing out into "weapons"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySam Lister14:52, 1 OCT 2018NewsChancellor Philip Hammond used forecasts he knew were inaccurate, it's been claimed "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Chancellor Philip Hammond used forecasts he knew were inaccurate during preparations for a no-deal Brexit , David Davis has claimed.  The former Brexit secretary accused Mr Hammond of undermining negotiations and claimed he turned predictions about the impact of crashing out into weapons. Speaking on the fringes of the Tory conference, Mr Davis said it drove him mad when the Chancellor would start talking about problems at crucial points in the EU exit talks. He said Mr Hammond was using a forecast which internally the reports said was inaccurate and did not reflect the future when preparations were being made for a no-deal outcome. Internally, that was the briefing going on inside, he added. So these are not forecasts, they are weapons.  Mr Davis said he was looking forward to being a backbencher during Treasury questions in the Commons. My first question to the Chancellor will be could he please name one forecast by the Treasury, or the OBR  or the Bank of England from the last 50 years that was right? Mr Davis said there would be immediate harm on all sides  Britain left the bloc without a deal. But he said it would be resolved swtly and criticised Mr Hammond for raising doubts. He said: It used to drive me mad sometimes when Government ministers, I'll name no names but you can make a very easy guess, he's been on the air today, we'd get to a negotiation point and suddenly somebody over here would start saying, 'Oh, we are in a terrible problem here, we can't do this, we can't do that, we are in dficulty, all these companies are going to leave the country'.

title: what tory brexit going look
story: NewsopinionThis is what the Tory Brexit is going to look likeThere's bad news for borders, badgers and BorisShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:31, 1 OCT 2018Updated12:34, 1 OCT 2018Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are 179 days until Brexit, they've got a full tank of prats, half a pack of loons, they're doomed and they're wearing blue rosettes. Welcome to the Conservative Party conference of 2018, where the Tories are trying to pretend they can organise a knees-up that doesn't somehow end in whacking themselves in the testicles.  It's day one, and they've already failed. Their Great Blond Hope has not only been victim of a Big Daddy splash by Lord Digby Jones, he's been impersonated by Phil 'Voldemort' Hammond and had his ideas characterised as not much good by David 'Mine Are No Better' Davis.  We are now uncomfortably close to the arbitrary date for leaving the European Union, chosen by a Prime Minister who herself was chosen because she wasn't someone else, and as is the way with things on horizons it looks worryingly like an out-of-control hydrogen explosion.  We all know what's happened - the referendum supposed to uny the Tories has caused them to turn on each other like cannibals who gave up chlorinated chicken for Lent, the question supposed to be settled for a generation remains unanswered, and Theresa May is still PM primarily because she isn't someone else.  So what is Brexit going to look like, under the Tories? 1. Project Oh Dear   Jeremy Hunt is a man who has more in common with an Anglepoise lamp than the rest of the human race. He can be pointed, turned on, and turned off again, but usually fails to illuminate anyone. He is now second-favourite to be Prime Minister next year, which should be adequate proof of just how boked the Tories are.  Boris is trolling, Sajid and Gavin are manoeuvring, Chris Grayling is in a siding outside Melton Mowbray and Hunt - a man who, the Leveson Inquiry heard, tried to hide behind trees to avoid journalists while still being visible to them - is now, let me say it again, one of the favourites. It's a bit like saying the green Opal Fruit is your favourite. Or that the USSR, which invaded countries that tried to leave it and killed millions, is just like the EU, which negotiates, even with people who don't know what they're doing. 2. Project You Can't Be Serious  Having toured the country in a bus promising to give our EU subscription to the NHS, the Tories have since said: a we'll still have to pay a subscription b it will be higher, without a rebate  c by the way, we'll be cutting &pound2.7bn off the NHS  Today the spiritual leader of the Brextremists has suggested we spend our foreign aid budget on saving elephants, because they remind him of Beethoven's Fth Symphony. Hang the education projects, stuff the small-scale charities who exist entirely because of foreign aid, and let's get all worked up about the 70 pence in every &pound100 national profit that we spend on foreigners. Boo hiss to foreigners! Elephants are British! Wait, what? 3. Project Is This Really The Best You Could Do  Brexit, the Tories are assuring us and their donors, will mean a bonfire of unnecessary rules and regulations about meaningless, bureaucratic tripe like child car seats, not getting killed at work and hiding your money from the taxman.  It gives us a chance to set our own rules such as only banning dangerous cladding 15 months after it burned 72 people alive, and only  it's on new buildings, which means all the people living in older properties can go sizzle.  It also won't matter  you sleep surrounded by highly-flammable material on the sixth floor, or  you don't have a sprinkler system, or the fire exits are blocked or non-existent. After Brexit, you won't want to live anyway. 4. Project Genuine Fear  The government of the UK is trying to exit a union it doesn't want while protecting one that it does. To do so they are relying on a referendum they say must be respected, while ignoring a referendum they say must be over-ridden.  All the people concerned were told beforehand that Brexit would spell the end of the Good Friday Agreement, a hard-won peace in Northern Ireland, and possibly the end of the Union altogether. That they have now, 6 months from doom, had this explained to them again by a comedian shows just what a bad joke the Tories are.  Patrick Kielty's dad was murdered by the Ulster Freedom Fighters for exposing their organised crime. The Tories' border solution involves asking those self-same people to pretend there's a border where there isn't one, and file paperwork well in advance before smuggling guns, drugs and people across 300 miles of hedge that we can't police. Laugh? You'll die. 5. Project It All Onto Someone Else   Presiding over economic chaos? Watching John Lewis go down the pan, the world turn against you, and Jacob Rees-Mogg destroying all his own suggestions by moving his investment funds to the EU and trying to get a trade deal with the People's Republic of Jam Jar Or Something Like That?   Well, why not shoot some more badgers. Not in the head, that's too quick. Kneecap them and watch them suffer. Burn some cattle, bankrupt some farmers, blame it all on the EU's crazy rules about bovine TB which isn't harmless so long as you pasteurise your milk, mostly doesn't kill cows and could easily be stopped with a vaccine  only we could be bothered.  When someone says 'but Brexit means we can abandon these rules! Save the badgers!' point out we still have to abide by EU rules  we want to sell beef, milk or cheese to the EU. And don't, for heaven's sake, let anyone say that the only way to change those rules is to, er, remain in the EU.  With a Tory Brexit, hard or soft, you're looking at Jeremy Hunt being in charge while making swingeing NHS cuts, making it quite the worst reboot of a franchise since Indiana Jones And The Hospital Of Doom.  You'll see people burning in another tower block before long, a fresh wave of terrorism when we haven't dealt with the current one, and Tories blaming badgers, migrants, and anything else that moved because, after Brexit, they'll no longer be able to blame the EU. The Tories have spent the past 40 years blaming Europe for all the things they cocked up themselves. Without the EU, people are going to blame the Tories. Which is why their days are numbered.

title: autistic boy 12 pelted toxic
story: NewsBoy, 12, pelted with 'toxic slime' by bullies causing agonising burns to his neckJack Poore was cycling to school when the mystery substance was thrown at himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDaniel HammondEleanor Perkins12:46, 1 OCT 2018Updated14:56, 1 OCT 2018NewsJack felt like his neck 'was on fire' "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn autistic 12-year-old has been left in agony and with 'burns' on his neck after bullies pelted him with a mystery toxic slime. Jack Poore was cycling to school when he was hit with a mystery acidic substance - thought to be mixed with toy slime. His mother, Tara, 37, received a panicked call from her son and immediately thought that Jack had been the victim of an acid attack. The schoolboy wiped the sludge from his neck and fell to the grass - with his body feeling like 'it was on fire'.  He was able to make it into his school reception, where staff were able to prise the rest of the 'green slime' off his neck area. School staff gave Jack medical assistance - but days later his neck still burns and he was left with a red 'blotchy mark' and 'tingles'. Tara, from Margate, Kent, said: He phoned me in state, saying he was in agony - he was crying, saying that his neck was on fire. Jack said he'd got some green slime on his neck and it was burning - I was thinking the worst, so I told him to go to the reception. When I got there, they'd washed it all off his neck but some was on his shirt, I had to take him home to keep an eye on him.  He is traumatised, but very lucky - I dread to think what would have happened  it had got on his face or in his eye. The mum-of-two thanked the school staff for their quick thinking and asked any witnesses of the incident to contact police. She said: Jack didn't have any exchanges on his way to school - he is a very quiet lad who keeps himself to himself. My son has only just built up the confidence to ride to school with his friends - he can't understand why anyone would do this. He only has a small group of friends, his autism means it takes him longer to connect with people.

story: NewsDriver's shock as 'potty is emptied out of car window' after 'child uses it in moving car'The potty was apparently dumped out of the window of a white Audi on Newmarket Road, CambridgeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachael McMenemyKelly-Ann Mills18:35, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/person-empties-potty-out-car-13338281,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driver was left horried after watching a potty apparently being dumped out of a car window and emptied onto road. Wojciech Karuzel was driving behind a white Audi on when he thought he noticed the dirty potty being poured out through an open window. Dashcam footage shows what seems to be a green potty being shoved out of the driver's side seat in the back of the car.  The person turns it over and the remnants can be seen dripping onto the street below, before the Audi drives off on Newmarket Road in Cambridge.  Mr Karuzel told Cambridgeshire Live: We noticed that someone had the potty outside the window and poured it on the street, it was weird and a little bit disgusting.   The 38-year-old noticed a young child moving around in the back of the car before the potty was poured out. He said: The other thing, I quickly noticed the child was jumping around in the car. He added: I think it's wrong what they did.  On Newmarket Road there are car parks one after another.  If the child needs a wee they can pull into a car park and do everything that's needed and then be on their way again, not while moving in traffic.  I was quite appalled.  Mr Karuzel, who has two children himself, said it's something no parent should do because not only is it disgusting but also unsafe.   It's so risky, it was unsafe, a child should be in a child car seat no matter what.  I could see the child was moving . It didn't look as  the child was strapped in.    As a father Mr Karuzel said he understands that parents might have been trying to be consistent with potty training but still thinks chucking a full potty out the window is never ok.  I might have understood trying to potty train a child and having that potty with them, but I would never think of it being used while moving. It shouldn't be done. He added: I have two children and I would never consider doing that. I would stop the car where possible and take the child to bushes or somewhere. It's the first time I've seen anything like that. The child safety is concerning. The child must be in the car seat  moving and even  the car is in traffic it should never be unbuckled. The incident happened on Wednesday, September 26 and Mr Karuzel says he's still shocked by what he saw. He said: It did take me by surprise. I did not expect a potty being emptied through the window. So that was very surprising.

title: eugenie wedding petition demanding no
story: NewsEugenie wedding: Petition demanding no public cash spent on princess's ceremony gets thousands of signaturesThe ninth-in-line to the throne is due to tie the knot with Jack Brooksbank in less than two weeks' timesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Coles14:48, 1 OCT 2018NewsThe security bill for the wedding is thought to be £2 million "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email More than 21,000 people have signed a petition demanding no public money be spent on Princess Eugenie's upcoming wedding .  Anti-monarchy group Republic started the petition demanding no public money goes towards the event and to publish a report of all costs to taxpayers. Princess Eugenie, 28, who carries out no royal duties, will marry fianc&eacute Jack Brooksbank at St George's Chapel at Windsor Castle on October 12th, just five months after her cousin Prince Harry did the same with Meghan Markle. The nuptials sparked anger when it was revealed the bash will be even bigger than Prince Harry’s. She and her fianc&eacute have invited more guests to St George’s Chapel in Windsor than the church will actually hold.  And she is even bringing in an expensive party planner David Beckham uses to help organise their wedding events which will span the whole weekend. A massive 850 guests will attend - 50 more than the chapel currently holds. By comparison, Harry and Meghan invited 600 guests. Like the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Eugenie and Jack will embark on a carriage ride to greet well-wishers. The security bill is thought to come in at around &pound2 million. The Newlyweds will travel down Castle Hill, onto the High Street and Park Street before ing to Windsor Castle via Cambridge Gate on the Long Walk and the roads along the route will be closed to traffic from 00.01am 12 October.  Republic said the event for the royal was shaping up to look more like a &pound35 million extravaganza than a wedding fit for a minor royal. The group added: Taxpayers should not be funding a private wedding, no matter who is getting married. If the Royals want to turn Eugenie and Jack's big day into a public event, they need to pick up the bill – all of it. The security bill will go in part towards policing the 1,200 members of the public outside the church in the grounds of the castle, who have been selected following a ballot. But once the nuptials are over and done with, that's when things will really get interesting. A post-wedding lunch hosted by the Queen on October 12 will be followed by a black-tie evening reception at Royal Lodge, Windsor, where Eugenie’s parents, the Duke and Duchess of York, still share a home despite orcing in 1996.

title: glamour model reveals trade secrets
story: NewsGlamour model and former lap dancer, 38, reveals the secrets of the tradeTanya Cox, from Hull, has been working in the industry for 11 years and says she's now breaking into the 'mature market' of glamour modellingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie CorcoranSophie Kitching09:34, 1 OCT 2018Updated10:57, 1 OCT 2018NewsTanya Cox, 38, has revealed the trade secrets of working as a glamour model "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA glamour model has revealed the secrets of the trade from what working on shoots is really like to meeting women who start modelling topless in their 50s. Tanya Cox, 38, from Hull, has been working in the industry since she was 27 but says she often thinks about getting a real job. She was scouted as a glamour model while working as a lap dancer and says her past experience enabled her to be comfortable in front of the camera. Despite loving her job, Tanya says she thought about giving up her career when jobs dried up after she turned 30, reports the Hull Daily Mail.  However, she's now finding success again as she breaks into the 'mature market'. How did you get into modelling and was it something you always wanted to do? I never really thought about doing any modelling work but whilst I was working as a lap dancer, I got approached by an agency and was asked  I would consider doing any modelling work.     I was quite shocked as I thought you had to be tall and skinny to do any kind of modelling but they reassured me that was just the fashion industry and that I was perfect for glamour. How old were you and how long have you been doing it? I came into the industry at 27 and I’m now 38. What was it like at first and what kind of things you were doing? Having already worked as a lap dancer for three years, I was very comfortable with modelling straight away. I think its the taking your clothes off bit that worries most new glamour models but as I had already been doing that for three years, that was the easy part, it was learning to find the light and what angles suited me that took the time the learn. Was you aware of any challenges the industry faced at the beginning? No, when I first came into the industry, everything seemed great, people were much more reliable with higher standards always putting quality first back then. But now its more quantity over quality and trying to get as much as possible shot in the time frame are booked for. Was there ever a point where you regretted getting into modelling? When I first turned 30, my work really quietened off as some companies considered me too old for the young market but I still looked too young to break the mature market. It was a very low point in my le and feeling my career slip away made me so depressed at times that I wished I never started. What has been the best things about it? Are there any moments which stand out where you loved it? I think for me, it helped me to find my own inner strength. I was guilty of never sticking up for myself when I was younger but now I'm the first to say when anyone is out of order, whether it's towards myself, a friend or even a stranger. Also through modelling and dancing, I have now met the best friends that I have ever had. I trust them completely and never doubt anymore that they all love me, as much as I love them. What has been some of the worst things about it? The worst thing about modelling is the high cancellation rates which has been getting worse and worse each year since 2010, but I don't think that is just an industry problem, I think society in general has forgotten its manners because I have noticed that more and more people cancel social meets with friends than ever before too.  Have you ever been judged based on your career? What do you think of that? Not in my personal le, but since my work started to quieten off and I have been trying to get a 'normal job', I do feel like employers are discriminating against me as I don't even seem to be able to get an interview these days, and when I was younger I always found it so easy to get work. When a place I worked at closed down, I had a new job within a week. How successful have you been? I felt pretty successful when I was younger but I do think I would of had a better career had I started when I was younger as it only lasted a few years before my peak ran out. I am now just starting to finally break the mature market, so fingers crossed I can make a success of that, but early days yet. Modelling must have changed since you started - have you seen that and in what way? It certainly has, all the technology keeps changing, I don't know how the photographers keep up. And unfortunately the budgets aren't as big anymore. I really miss the days of make-up artists and clothing departments on all shoots, but these days its only the very biggest companies that provide those now and for most shoots we just get a list of what types clothing to bring with us and have to do our own hair and make-up. Do you think it will change in the future and in what way? We are seeing dferent types of models coming through now We are and I love that we are now celebrating ersity with models now coming in dferent shapes, sizes, styles and ages. I met a new model on set recently who had just started doing topless modelling at 52. Social media has also come to the forefront and many models experience trolling - is that something you've experienced? Yes, I have had a few negative comments but, for every bad comment I get, there is always at least 20 positive comments to counter-act it and the troll then usually ends up getting loads of grief for his/her comment anyway so it always back fires on them.

story: NewsInside squalid flat where tenants dumped 50 bags of waste before fleeing owing £1,700 rentThe landlord of the Grimsby property said the tenants left owing £1,700 in rent as well as weeks worth of rent to clean and restore the flatShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'LearyConnor Lynch10:19, 1 OCT 2018Updated10:22, 1 OCT 2018NewsThe kitchen was left in a horric state "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the disgusting mess tenants left a flat in as their horried landlord discovered 50 bags of rubbish, rotting food and smashed furniture. The landlord of the Grimsby property said the tenants left owing &pound1,700 in rent as well as weeks worth of rent to clean and restore the flat.  After going to inspect the house when they left, he said he was disgusted at the state it had been left in, with cupboard doors ripped off, waste scattered over the floor and thick grime left on surfaces, reports Grimsby Live .  The landlord, known only as Gary, said they ruined the kitchen, which was completely covered in dirt and grime, with bags of rubbish and waste left scattered all over it. Many of the cupboard doors were broken off of their hinges. They also found that doors throughout the house had been broken, the carpets had been damaged beyond repair, electrical sockets had been knocked out of the walls and were left hanging loose and the bathroom had also been left in a state of disrepair.  The problems were not just found in the house however - there was a huge pile of rubbish bags in the back garden. He claimed they had also left the property owing more than &pound1,700 in rent after experiencing problems with their benefits. His property manager Anne, said it has completely put them off renting to tenants who are on housing benefits, saying that they have had numerous problems with people on Universal Credit going into arrears. Despite the shocking state of the house, the landlord managed to completely refurbish the property in just a week, after Nottingham Council contacted them about housing a family in need.  Anne said: After we found the house in such an awful condition, we were steadfast against ever renting to people on housing benefits or renting through the local authority. But then Nottingham Council contacted us, explaining that they were in urgent need of some help to house a desperate family. At first we were apprehensive, but the council offered to provide us with three months rent in advance so we could make the necessary repairs. We ended up giving the house a complete make-over, with a new kitchen, carpets, paint, electrics and doors. If this never happened then we would still be struggling to have the house repaired, as the lack of rent and sheer amount of damage would have left us out severely out of pocket. This is not the only property that this landlord has had issues with in Grimsby, as another was ruined by squatters, after another tenant, who was on Universal Credit, was evicted after owing thousands in rent.  The squatters had started a fire in the kitchen of the property, took drugs and even kicked through the wall into a neighbour's house. Anne continued: Since the introduction of Universal Credit we have had constant problems with tenants falling into rental arrears, the whole system just doesn't seem fit for purpose. Many times when a tenant goes onto the benefit system, there is no communication with us as landlords, and for the first few months we often get no rent paid. To try and fix this we have sent documents to tenants and the Department of Work and Pensions, providing them with the correct forms so that rent is paid directly to us, but we have just hit brick wall after brick wall while doing this.

title: mum autistic boy 7 handful
story: NewsMum of autistic boy, 7, with handful of friends makes plea to strangers ahead of his birthdayAlfie's mum Bronya wants to show how loved he is and teach him that it doesn't matter that he is dferentShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom BevanKatie Timms12:14, 1 OCT 2018NewsBronya wants as many people as possible to send Alfie a card "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mother of a seven-year-old autistic boy who struggles to make friends as he cannot speak is appealing for strangers to send him birthday cards. Bronya Thompson, 30, is hoping as many people as possible send her son Alfie a card for his eighth birthday as he loves opening and reading them. The youngster is non-verbal and can only communicate using sign language. He also has a rare chromosome deletion and is one of just eight who suffer from the condition in the world.  Bronya said that due to Alfie's health battles and his struggles to speak he has just a handful of friends as he really struggles to make them and there were only six other children in his class at school. Alfie also has a small family but his mum wants to get him a few more cards for him to open on his birthday on Saturday, October 13, to show how loved he is and teach him that it doesn't matter that he is dferent. She said: Alfie doesn't like toys but loves cards and reading them. It would be amazing to get him a few more he can open on his day to show how loved he really is, and it doesn't matter  you're dferent. We will never know  speech will ever come. He also has hypermobility and struggles to walk and needs a wheelchair, but as you can see from his smile he has a great sense of humour.  Bronya said she also wanted to raise awareness of her son's condition, and that  members of the public see an older child who appears to be having a tantrum, they are probably having a meltdown. I've had a lot of people tut and give comments when Alfie been screaming in town, she added. It's important to remember you cannot always tell that someone is autistic by looking at them. Autism is a disability, not a disease, and does not go away. Everyone who has autism is dferent, some may need more support and some may need less. People with autism find it hard to express themselves, say what they need, or how they feel.

story: NewsWomen are 'closing the infidelity gap': Why 'more and more wives are cheating on their husbands'Increasing numbers of women are prepared to act on their thoughts of other men -despite still loving their other halves, an author claimsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans14:37, 1 OCT 2018News" content="https:i2-prod.mirror/incoming/article8540226.ece/ALTERNATES/s615/3_Couple-in-bed.jpg"/More and more women are said to be cheating on their spouses  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWomen are closing the infidelity gap, experts believe.  More and more females are said to be 'rejecting' monogamy and cheating on their spouses - despite saying they still love them.  They are now reportedly more likely to cheat than three decades ago, with increased autonomy, earning power and opportunity. Women are 40 per cent more likely now to cheat on their husbands than in 1990, says best-selling author, Wednesday Martin. She adds that it appears rising numbers of women are prepared to act on their thoughts of other men, despite being in marriages. Wednesday, whose new book 'Untrue' is out this month, came across a number of real women’s voices and stories when carrying out research.   In a piece for the Daily Mail , she describes how one woman, called Erica, didn't want to give up on her marriage when the passion disappeared.  Instead, after years of sexual disappointment, the 46-year-old went online to search for someone - and ended up having a passionate affair. Wednesday says the women she encountered had ying problems, from 'routine' sex that didn't fulfil them, to no intimacy, to a craving for novelty. Crucially, none of these women wanted to give up on their marriages or loved their husbands any less, explains the author. While male infidelity used to be at a much higher rate than female infidelity, experts believe the gap is increasingly narrowing. One reason is that more women are out at work, where they are apart from their partners and exposed to potential lovers, some experts say. Another reason could be technology - with women able to discreetly have affairs through social media and apps, according to Wednesday.  And some believe women in long-term relationships are just as likely to lose interest in their other halves over time as men are. Wednesday says that what she has discovered through research is that women’s libidos are far stronger and more adventurous than we thought. Her research included speaking to women of a range of ages, as well as investigating scientic and evolutionary theories. In her Mail article, she says some scientists believe women get bored of sleeping with the same man, and desire others, for evolutionary reasons. They need new experiences to stay interested, according to these scientists. According to Wednesday's book, female infidelity is now far from uncommon. story: NewsDad 'super glued baby's eyes and mouth shut to stop her crying before burying her under pillows'Johnnie Lee Carter, 29, was arrested after the incident at a Texas hotel nearly 300 miles from the suspected crime sceneShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris Murphy16:50, 1 OCT 2018Updated16:51, 1 OCT 2018NewsJohnnie Lee Carter, 29, was arrested Monday in El Paso"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad was so desperate to stop his one-year-old crying that he allegedly glued her eyes and mouth shut.  Police in Odessa, Texas were called to a hotel room where they found a two-month-old buried under pillows and blankets.  The dad is also accused of beating his daughter but he absconded before the cops arrived. Local outlet WQAD reports authorities have now arrested the fugitive Texan father. They said Johnnie Lee Carter, 29, was arrested Monday in El Paso on a felony charge of injury to a child causing serious bodily injury, according to the Odessa Police Department. title: brave eight year old girl
story: NewsBrave eight-year-old girl tackles gun-wielding robbers after they mug her dad leaving her with broken noseBrielle Minia was playing in the driveway outsider her home when four men posing as DVD sellers threatened her dadShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter11:02, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/eight-year-old-girl-tackles-13339533,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the astonishing moment an eight-year-old girl tackles gun-wiedling robbers moments after they mugged her father. Schoolgirl Brielle Minia was playing on the driveway outside her home when the four men walked past posing as DVD sellers last Thursday afternoon in Cavite, Philippines. The three masked men approached her dad - who had just ed home from work in a white 4x4 - and held him up at gunpoint to steal his cash while one of the gang raided the family home. The group ran back down the driveway in the opposite direction - with the only person between them and their getaway motorcycles being the little girl, who was walking back to see what the noise was.  Wearing a pink dress and pigtails, Brielle bravely lunged at the same man who had been holding the silver semi-automatic handgun. She ripped open his bag, sending the contents he had stolen onto the flood. The youngster frantically tried to scoop it up as the robber towered over her then made a break for freedom.  But incredibly, the fearless youngster climbed to her feet and sprinted after the robber before hurling herself at them for a second time as they climbed onto their bikes. Brielle was kicked to the ground and suffered cuts and bruises to her face, hands and a suspected broken nose.  The youngster spent two nights in hospital, before ing home and bravely declaring: ''I'll get them next time.'' Brielle said that she was ''not afraid'' of the ''cowards'' and would do the same thing again. She added: ''I'm so angry they stole my daddy's money. If I ever see them again they'll be sorry.''
